required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Risk Factors of Meconium Obstruction and Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Cohort for Finding Risk Factors of Meconium Obstruction and Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Preterm Infants

brief_summary.textblock:
Although the pathophysiology of meconium obstruction of prematurity (MOP) is not clear, it is known that the decrease of the intestinal peristalsis due to decreased intestinal perfusion during antenatal or perinatal period. Recently, the level of citrulline has been used as an index of function and injury of the small intestine State. This study aimed to evaluate citrulline level of cord blood as a marker for early detection and observe changes in intestinal blood flow in MOP patient.
And We aimed to confirm the efficacy of the AT/ET ratio (ratio of the pulmonary artery time-to-peak velocity interval to the right ventricular ejection time) of the prenatal pulmonary artery as a noninvasive predictor of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

primary_outcome.measure: Comparison of citrulline level between the meconium obstruction group and the normal feeding advance group
primary_outcome.description: check the citrulline llevel from blood at birth

primary_outcome.measure: Comparison of prenatal AT/ET ratio of fetal pulmonary artery between respiratory distress syndrome group and the normal respiration group
primary_outcome.description: Check the AT/ET ratio of fetal pulmonary artery within 10 days before birth

clinical_study.condition: Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Premature Infant

biospec_descr.textblock: Blood sample at birth for citrulline level analysis urine sample at the first day of life for fatty acid binding protein analysis

study_pop.textblock: Premature infants born less than 34 weeks who were admitted in neonatal intensive care unit at Seoul National University Children's Hospital

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- premature infants born less than 34 weeks from mother with pregnancy induced hypertension, pre-eclampsia or eclampsia
Exclusion Criteria:
- major congenital anomalies
- infants with hypotension while using inotropics
